results.title: The Edge of the World
results.creator_credit: Michael Powell, Joe Rock, GFD and Rock
results.brief_description: Life, love and death on Foula, a remote Shetland Island. Rare for its time, a vigorous location drama in the Flaherty tradition, sometimes naive, usually exhilarating. The original film made in 1937 with additional material filmed in colour in 1978. Stars Niall MacGinnis, Belle Chrystal, John Laurie and Finlay Currie.

results.title: In the Shadow of the Sun
results.creator_credit: Derek Jarman, James MacKay and Dark Pictures
results.brief_description: Derek Jarman shot the main sequences for this, his first lengthy film in the early ‘70s. Described as ‘very personal’ with a dream- like repetitive quality, the film expresses a mythology and dabbles with ideas relating to magic alchemy and ritual, allowing dream-images to drift and collide at random.

results.title: The Quare fellow
results.creator_credit: Arthur Dreifuss, Anthony Havelock-Allan, BLC and Bryanston Films
results.brief_description: A condemned killer awaits his execution. A funny tragedy, a happy- go-lucky horror show, a gay little wake for the dead who have died in the name of justice - the kind of justice that demands a life for a life. Like Brendan Behan’s play, the picture ignores the rational arguments against capital punishment. It simply takes the audience inside an Irish prison and bolts the gate, and then with a world of Irish charm and humour shows everybody how it feels to live in a cell - and die on a rope.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arthur Dreifuss, Anthony Havelock-Allan, BLC and Bryanston Films

results.title: Don Giovanni
results.creator_credit: Joseph Losey, Michel Seydoux, Camera One and Gaumont-Opera
results.brief_description: Dame Kiri Te Kanawa and Ruggerio Raimondi star in Mozart’s opera “Don Giovanni”, inspired by the exploits of the womaniser Don Juan and set in the palaces and countryside surrounding Venice.

results.title: I hate your guts = The Intruder = The Informer
results.brief_description: After thirty commercial successes, Roger Corman here tackled the contemporary theme of racism and delivered an exemplary piece of tough-minded, hard-hitting low-budget filmmaking. William Shatner, exuding a sleazy but effective charm, plays a power-hungry demagogue who arrives in a small Southern town reluctantly facing up to desegregation. His impassioned speeches stir up the white community, revive the Ku Klux Klan and lead to attacks on black families and a near-lynching. Adapted from the novel by Charles Beaumont.

results.title: Alexander Nevsky
results.creator_credit: D Vasiliev, Sergei Eisenstein and Mosfilm
results.brief_description: Sergei Eisenstein’s patriotic masterpiece of the exploits of 13th Century Russian hero Prince Alexander Nevsky was his first sound film and featured a special musical score by composer Sergey Prokovief. The Prince, as chosen leader of the people of Novgorod, vanquished the Teutonic Knights on the ice of Lake Peipus. The characters, boldly drawn and unencumbered with psychological details, are monumental figures. All are conceived as they are imagined today and as they survive in folklore. The impressive cast includes Nikolai Cherkassov as Nevsky.

results.title: The Black Stallion Returns
results.creator_credit: Robert Dalva, Francis Ford Coppola, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Zoetrope Studios
results.brief_description: A youth named Alec and a fabled Arabian steed survived a shipwreck and became inseparable friends in The Black Stallion, the first of Walter Farley’s 16-book series to be made into a highly successful film. In the sequel The Black Stallion returns, the horse is reclaimed by its rightful owner, beginning an odyssey to North Africa and a culture alien to Alec. Through his persistence, Alec gains new insights into courage, perseverance and honour. This action-filled adventure tale joins the initial film as a timeless classic. Stars Kelly Reno and Ferdy Mayne

results.title: The Red pony
results.creator_credit: Lewis Milestone and Charles K Felman Group
results.brief_description: John Steinbeck’s classic is brought to life with an outstanding cast and a fine script. It is a tender, moving story about the conflict between a nine year old boy, his father and the family’s hired hand. A small red pony becomes the focal point of the complex human relationships at the ranch and is the catalyst for the boy’s growth into manhood. Starring Myrna Loy and Robert Mitchum.

results.title: The Clinic
results.creator_credit: David Stevens, Bob Weis, Robert Le Tet, Generation Films and The Film House
results.brief_description: Take an innocent intern on his first day at a VD clinic, add in a bunch of doctors and nurses who have seen it all before then mix it all up with the craziest and funniest patients you’ll ever meet. That’s the recipe for this highly infectious comedy. Stars Chris Haywood and Simon Burke.

results.title: Caravaggio
results.creator_credit: Derek Jarman, Sarah Radclyffe and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: An imaginary biopic of the Italian painter who died in 1610. Caravaggio was the last, perhaps the greatest, and certainly the most controversial painter of the Italian Renaissance. While Caravaggio’s paintings reflect an increasingly profound and original awareness, his private life was fraught with prostitutes, brawls, duels, arrests and libel cases, culminating in 1606 with a murder. Caravaggio’s bisexuality, his propensity for violence, and his scorn for court conventions made him the scoundrel of the Italian aristocracy.
